newsitem.title: UK: Brazil Bradys rise on news of central bank change.
newsitem.headline: Brazil Bradys rise on news of central bank change.

text.p: Brazilian Brady bonds extended gains scored late on Tuesday in New York following news of a key change of post at the country's central bank, traders said on Wednesday.

The announcement that Brazilian International Affairs director Gustavo Franco had been nominated to replace central bank President Gustavo Loyola continued to boost the price of the country's debt instruments.

"Following news Franco was taking over the central bank in Brazil, "C" bonds traded up about another 1/2 point from yesterday's closing levels," said one trader at a European investment bank in London.
Franco's position must still be confirmed by the Senate.

At 1045 GMT, Brazilian "C" bonds which rose 3/8 following the news on Tuesday, were 1/4 higher at 84-1/2 bid. The country's par bonds were 3/8 higher at 72-5/8 and its discount bonds were 3/8 stronger at 86-5/8 bid.
One trader said Asian buying of Brazilian paper added to the positive tone in the country's debt.
In the broader market, emerging market debt traders said Brady bond prices continued to trend higher on the back of a strong U.S. Treasury market.
"Treasuries are a bit firmer and everyone is convinced this is a proper bull market," said a trader at a U.S. investment bank in London.
The Brady bond market continued to ride a wave of euphoria despite the release of key U.S. economic data due later this week, they added.
Economic reports include U.S. second-quarter real GDP figures on Thursday and July unemployment on Friday.
In Eastern Europe, Bulgarian IABs were 1/4 higher at 77-1/2 bid and Russian Vneshekonombank dollar loans were 3/8 firmer at 94-3/4 bid.
